document.docAuthor: Calcinai, Barbara, Bavestrello, Giorgio, Bertolino, Marco, Pica, Daniela, Wagner, Daniel & Cerrano, Carlo
document.masterDocTitle: Sponges associated with octocorals in the Indo-Pacific, with the description of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sponges associated with octocorals in the Indo-Pacific, with the description of four new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Examined material. Sample K 5 : Hawai’i, O’ahu Island , 1 m ,
31 August 2003
.

Description. Pulpy sponge, about 1.5 mm thick, massively encrusting a branch of
Carijoa riisei
, 7 cm long (
Fig. 17
A). The anthocodiae are free from the sponge (
Fig. 17
A). Surface macroscopically smooth, consistency soft and tough. Beige in ethanol (
Fig. 17
A).

Skeleton. The ectosomal skeleton is not clearly observable; it is mainly composed of tylotes and onychaetes protruding from the surface and making it hispid (
Fig. 17
B); paucispicular tracts of tylotes are tangentially disposed. The choanosome is an irregular reticulation of uni- or paucispicular tracts of styles. In general the skeleton appears isotropic.

Spicules. Styles frequently curved (
Fig. 17
C), 245 – ( 254 ± 6.9 ) – 270 x 3.75 – ( 7.8 ± 2.7 ) – 10 μm. Tornotes with rounded and microspined points (
Fig. 17
D), 187.5 – ( 199.3 ± 5.8 ) – 207.5 x 2.5 – ( 3.9 ± 0.7 ) – 5 μm. Onychaetes separable in two size classes with numerous intermediate forms. Onychaetes I, finely spined, with symmetrical tips (
Fig. 17
E), 160 – ( 170 ± 10.6 ) – 180 μm; onychaetes II with clear asymmetrical tips and slightly spread long spines (
Fig. 17
F), 40 – ( 49 ± 8.6 ) – 60 μm.

Van
Soest, 1984
re-described the paralectotype of
Thalysias ignis Duchassaing & Michelotti ( 1864 )
, and reported the presence of two size classes of onychaetes (about 50 μm and 180 μm in length); the same author also recognized, in his material from Caribbean, two distinct size classes of onychaetes, with numerous intermediate sizes. On the contrary,
Hechtel ( 1965 )
and
Wiedenmayer ( 1977 )
detected the presence of a single category only. Bhattacharya analysis based on onychaete lengths shows the presence of two main size classes corresponding to those of Duchassaing & Michelotti ( 1864 ) sensu Van
Soest ( 1984 :
Tab. 7
and
Fig. 18
)
. The most frequent class (group 1 ), 54.6 %, comprises onychaetes between 40–60 μm (
Tab. 7
and
Figs. 17
F; 18 ); the second class with a wide population of spicules (group 3 ), 34.5 %, comprises onychaetes of about 160–180 μm in length (
Tab. 7
and
Figs. 17
E; 18 ). An additional small group (group 2 ), 10.9 %, with a mean of 110 μm is probably composed of growing onychaetes I (
Tab. 7
and
Fig. 18
).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 7.
Tedania (Tedania) ignis (Duchassaing & Michelotti, 1864)
. Analysis with Bhattacharya’s method indicating the numbers of identified cohorts (groups) of onychaetes, the mean length for each cohort and the number of spicules present in each cohort. S.d. Standard deviation; S.I. Separation index; separation of the groups is generally unreliable when the S.I. value is below 2. N.a. not applicable.

FIGURE 17.
Tedania (Tedania) ignis (Duchassaing & Michelotti, 1864)
. A, Pulpy sponge, massively encrusting the axis of
Carijoa riisei
; B, Hispid surface of the sponge; C, Style; D, Tylote and its microspined extremity; E, Onychaete I and magnification of the extremities and the central part; F, Onychaete II and magnification of the extremities.

FIGURE 18. Size/frequency distribution of onychaete lengths in
Tedania (Tedania) ignis
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
In the absence of molecular evidence we can not exclude that
T. ignis
constitutes a species complex, comprising morphologically indistinct species.
